Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evolution Systems On Time-Dependent Domains: Study Of Dynamics, Stability, And Coarsening

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this collaborative research project is to understand and quantify the key differences between structure formation and evolution in extended systems on time-fixed and time-dependent spatial domains. Achieving these objectives will require the development of new methods based on the synergy of theoretical tools and experimental capabilities, and will lead to new advances in dynamical bifurcation theory. The study will lead to new models describing the nonlinear evolution of pattern wavelength on time-dependent domains for comparison with those on fixed domains, including the generation of phase slips via Eckhaus instability. Pattern coarsening on time-dependent domains will be contrasted with that on fixed domains. To validate the theory and provide a testbed for theoretical ideas and findings, an extensive experimental study of Faraday waves on time-dependent domains will be performed.

There are many natural systems which evolve on time-dependent spatial domains ranging from transport-reaction processes - crystal growth, metal casting, gas-liquid and gas-solid reaction systems - to classical electromagnetic cavity resonators with moving walls, quantum mechanical problems, fluid motion, fluid-structure interaction, and formation of structure and morphology in biology, to name but a few. Therefore, revealing the dynamics on time-dependent domains is important both from fundamental and practical points of view. At the technological level, the outcome of this program will provide fundamental insights into the behavior of extended systems on time-dependent domains, which in turn should lead to advances in structure prediction and control in the above-mentioned applications. At the dissemination level, the studied phenomena present a great opportunity to introduce people to science and technology at varying degrees of complexity and to encourage scientific training. Graduate, undergraduate, and regional high-school students will benefit not only through classroom instruction, but will also be provided with firsthand research experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project concerns pattern formation in growing domains. The basic issue is this: if the domain stretches the wavelength of any pattern within also stretches but most pattern-forming systems generate patterns with a preferred wavelength or at least a range of preferred wavelengths (think of a pattern of convection rolls or the waves on the surface of a vertically vibrating container of water). This means that new wavelengths have to be continually injected into the system as the domain grows and this project examines mechanisms whereby this is accomplished. The key is provided by the notion of a phase slip -- new wavelengths are injected at phase slip locations while the phase slips themselves are triggered by a modulational instability called the Eckhaus instability. In time-independent systems this instability is well understood but this is not the case for systems on growing domains in which the pattern wavelength is continually stretching, and more generally for partial differential equations with time-dependent coefficients. The PI has developed techniques for studying this instability in growing domains enabling him to analyze the consequences of bifurcation delay: the pattern drifts through the Eckhaus instability but only responds to the instability after a time delay. There are numerous applications of this type of theory. For example, when a falling drop impacts the surface of a liquid one observes the familiar growing crown of ejecta. In this system the rim of the crown is continually extending and the number of spikes needs to adjust to this growth. In other systems the propagation of a pattern into a spatially uniform state may be driven by phase slips that inject new wavelengths into the pattern forcing the pattern to expand. The PI has sought to understand the symbiotic relationship between the phase slip rate and the speed of the resulting invasion front. Finally, there are many potential applications in biology, where growth triggers transitions, or the number of stripes on an animal coat needs to keep pace with its growth.

The PI also studied states of partial synchrony in systems of identical phase oscillators with nonlocal coupling. In such states, sometimes referred to as chimera states, some of the oscillators oscillate in phase while the rest have 'random' phase, i.e., ordered or coherent motion is embedded in a noisy incoherent background. The PI has studied systems with multiple coherent clusters and their stability properties and discovered that such regions of coherence can in some cases propagate through the system without change of shape. Inhomogeneities in the oscillator properties can trap these moving structures and generate complex dynamics. A two-dimensional array of such oscillators may exhibit coherent regions in the form of a spiral that rotates around an incoherent core, and this core is itself subject to instabilities. In carrying out this work the PI has sought to bring to this interesting dynamical system ideas from pattern formation and has been developing the notion of synchronization fronts which kick incoherent oscillators into synchrony as they pass, or vice versa.

Synchronization is also the subject of the third topic. Here the PI studied synchronization in systems of oscillators with time-dependent properties, and identified a sequence of resonances between the time scale for a phase slip and the time scale over which the oscillator properties vary. Similar behavior arises in systems described by partial differential equation with time-dependent coefficients and the PI showed that a similar sequence of resonances arises between the time scale over which a spatially localized structure grows through the nucleation of new wavelengths and the period of the temporal forcing. These resonances describe parameter regimes in which the localized structure breathes with no net growth, as well as other regions where the structure on average grows and others where on average it shrinks. These regions are separated by parameter intervals with complex behavior including so-called canard behavior whereby the state of the system follows for a time a state that would be unstable in the absence of the temporal forcing. Our calculations represent the first computation of such states in time-dependent partial differential equations and the theory developed by the PI suggests an approach to studying this novel behavior.

The ideas and techniques developed by the PI should prove highly relevant in areas of the physical and biological sciences where growth triggers transitions and generates new dynamical phenomena. For example, the theory may find application in ecology where seasonal variation in growth conditions may strongly effect vegetation cover in arid regions. Likewise, the notion of synchronization in time-dependent systems is of great importance in systems where synchronization or phase coherence are desirable, for example, for signal detection but the system is imperfect and subject to fluctuations.

The project resulted in 10 publications and two completed PhD Theses. The results were presented at a number of international conferences and workshops.
